Complete a table for each SLO. If an SLO is assessed by more than one measure, complete tables for each measure. Duplicate the table as needed to accommodate the number of measures.
Title of the Measure: Rating Collected Student Written Works—Constructing Mathematical Arguments
Describe How the Measure Aligns to the SLO
An important skill in the mathematical sciences is to make arguments and to write proofs. Collected
student works would be measuring student abilities in these areas.
The assessment would be done in the following courses under the supervision of the two academic coordinators.

In each area, exam questions have been selected by the academic coordinator in consultation with the instructor(s) for these courses. These questions will be used to assess that particular SLO according to an established rubric. The exam questions will be given each semester the course is offered.
For the first academic coordinator (currently Michael Matthews):
Majors with no area of conc.: Math 3230- Intro
For the second academic coordinator (currently Slava
Operations Research: Math 4756 - Intro to Probability and Statistics I
Data Science: Math 4756 - Intro to Probability and Statistics I
Pre-Actuarial Science: Math 4740 - Intro to Probability and Statistics I
: Math 4756 - Intro to Probability and Statistics I

The frequency will depend on the core area. It will be at least once a year as discussed in point 5 above. It will be done each time the courses listed above are offered. For some courses, this is every Fall or Spring semester. For other courses, it is once a year.

The assessment coordinator for that area of concentration will collect exam questions as described above. The student’s work on that exam question will be rated into exactly one of the following four categories: Unsatisfactory, Satisfactory, Good, Very Good.
proficiency target is that at least 70% of students would be rated as either Good or Very Good(See Proficiency Threshold discussion above).
SLO 2: Be able to communicate mathematics effectively in oral form.
Title of the Measure: Student Oral Presentations
Describe How the Measure Aligns to the SLO
Initially, the total number of oral presentations given by math majors would be noted each semester.

These presentations could be in a number of different venues or settings, such as departmental colloquiums, national or sectional meetings of mathematical groups or associations, presentations given to local companies, etc. Eventually, an oral presentation of some kind might be mandatory, at least for all
Mathematics majors declaring a core area of concentration.
This would be done each semester.
When oral presentations are required, those students declaring a core area of study.
Describe: Students will present a sample of their work at one of the venues/settings
Describe: At least 70% of students will give some sort of oral presentation before they graduate.
SLO 3: Demonstrate substantive comprehension of the major ideas in the core areas of their fields of study.
Title of the Measure: Rating Collected Student Written Works-Overall Comprehension
Describe How the Measure Aligns to the SLO
works will be collected on an exam question which measures overall comprehension. It is possible that one or more of the exam questions collected to measure SLO 1 above could also be used to
This is the same as for SLO 1. See Point 5 above for SLO 1.

The frequency will depend on the core area. It will be at least once a year as discussed in point 5 above. It will be done each time the courses listed above are offered. For some courses, this is every semester. For other courses, it is once a year.

The assessment coordinator for that area of concentration will collect exam questions as described above. The student’s work on that exam question will be rated into exactly one of the following four categories: Unsatisfactory, Satisfactory, Good, Very Good.
proficiency target is that at least 70% of students would be rated as either Good or Very Good(See Proficiency Threshold discussion above).

We want to collect data for more semester before making any concrete plans. This semester’s data is incomplete because of lack of everyone participating (in reporting who has presented) and due to loss of data (due to faculty passing away, moving, retiring, and even forgetting since for some of the seniors it’s possible they presented a few years ago).
